ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
none
none
We met virtually and usually had work sessions on our art projects during class time, and when our projects were done we'd go through everybody's projects and critique them.

A 2 hr class twice a week over zoom felt a bit fatiguing at times, but when we were actively working on drawing, it pasted by very quickly. The weeks where we had to sit through 4 hours of critiques over zoom was the only point where the class felt lacking over zoom.
independent drawing/project time outside of class
Bi-weekly virtual seminar and office hours if needed

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Encouraged me to think creatively and develop my drawing skills
I learned how to analyze and appreciate other people's work during critiques. I also learned how to use charcoal/conte crayon.
I learned how to draw and experiment with different materials.
I learnt how to shade, create 3D artwork and produce art in forms I would not typically consider
learned out to draw
Lines and line weight, still life, self-portrait, collage, methods with using color pencil and charcoal
Learned various ways of translating what I see into art. Also learned to effectively critique others work

I learned a lot about what it means to create art -- not just drawing but also collage. This class doesn't necessarily teach specific skills as much as it does ways of looking at the world and thinking about creating.
How to draw, how to examine art

I learned to draw! I started off with minimal knowledge after taking a high school drawing class, but at the end of the semester I actually feel like I have drawing talent - which it honestly unbelievable.
I learned about how to build a final piece, from sketching to material design to adding and incorporating criticism.

I learned the fundamentals of drawing! I am a non-art student, so this was a truly special way for me to engage with different skills and develop creatively as a student. It was like re-discovering my childhood!
I learned a lot about different art forms and ways of expressing emotions through non-traditional art.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked how assignments were open-ended, and it was always fun to consider and view my classmates' works during critique

Strengths: lots of individual time with the prof and teaching fellow to discuss your work. You really get to flesh out the storytelling/conceptual goals of each project.  Weakness: I don't think my technical abilities improved at all during this course, the things we were prompted to think about had a lot more to do with conceptual derivations. Most of the class is not comprised of serious art majors, but I believe it could stand to benefit from a basic introduction to the principles of drawing.
There was less formal drawing practice and teaching than I would have liked. Did not teach perspective.

strengths: engaging, interesting
weaknesses: requires lots of time and could do with more guidance
it was a good course but i would add another drawing assignemnt to the course - it did not seem like enough

There weren't too many assignments, which was perfect. I was able to commit time into my work to create something I was satisfied with. The freedom with the final project was also very nice. I had a great time working on the final project knowing that I had free rein over my approaches and final outcome.

The main strength is how much fun it is to have a chance to draw and make art for a class. The assignments are interesting and have a lot of room for personalization. I think the only weakness is the virtual format, which is necessitated by the pandemic. But it honestly was not that bad -- there was still a vibe of collaboration even though we were never in the same room.

Strength - attentive nature of prof & TA, really wanted to make sure every individual in the class was improving and succeeding

Weakness - the crits felt pretty long over zoom, and I can think they are much more bearable in person. Also they rarely stuck to the time allotted for each student and often strung the conversation out longer than I felt it need to.
More concrete feedback would be helpful. Otherwise, great class!

The class was really special and especially because we had a phenomenal group of people who were engaged with the material and excited to contribute to each other's pieces. I thought this class did a really good job of turning an in-person studio into a virtual classroom. The only part I found kind of difficult was our method of sharing our work with each other. Although this has a lot to do with simply being virtual, I wonder if there's some other way to be able to see people's work easier while in progress, like scanning regardless of what stage we're in, or doing more virtual art.

More class/guidance! I loved this course so much. I wish that we were able to recieve more assignments or ways to continue drawing beyond the actual course. The assignment prompts force you to work on certain techniques that otherwise you may ignore. I wish I could continue that beyond the scope of the class.
This course was great at letting students explore what they enjoyed in art. It would be improved if there was more structure and also clearer expectations set upfront.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Hard to get a sense of scale sometimes of student drawing, but virtual drawing sessions and critiques ran smoothly

The online format made it impossible to make friends or discuss things as fluidly as you would have been able to in a studio, but that isn't the course's fault. Maybe separate students into breakout rooms so they can talk during work sessions?
Once we all had drawing materials, it went well, except for being unable to receive in person feedback as we drew, likely resulting in the minimal formal teaching that I touched on above.

The virtual lectures worked well, we were all muted until necessary. 
More breakout rooms could have been utilised
i thought it was perfect

Deadlines and final presentations were flexible. Students who wished for more time could request to present on the second day of critiques. I also really appreciated the option to get supplies through the class (either by pickup on campus or through shipping for remote students). I already purchased supplies before the class art kits were bought, so I was able to receive a reimbursement.
Showing art work through zoom worked best through screen share instead of occasionally holding up work to camera.

I think the method of critiques where everyone took pictures of their work and screenshared it during their turn worked as well as it could for a virtual class. Not being in a physical studio is a drawback, but I think the format used in this class is just about as good as it could be without a real physical space.

Since this was an art class I feel like there were more challenges because of the pandemic, but overall the class flowed as smoothly as it could. People would share images of their artwork and then the class would talk about the work over Zoom. Given the constraints of being at home, some assignments had to be changed from their original forms, like the self-portraits we did at home in lieu of a shared model in an art class. However, Professor Keegan encouraged us to use our limitation to our benefit, and our final projects were more diverse than what would have happened in a normal setting.
I thought they did a fantastic job! Each person received proper drawing materials, and they made sure you felt comfortable sharing your work with your peers.
(this is what my response to 4 was about)
I thought this course did a great job transitioning to the virtual environment. I actually felt incredibly connected to my other classmates too.
I really liked having the first few classes where we drew for 1 minute, 5 minutes, 10 minutes etc because I think it kept everyone engaged and excited.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you would like to draw in a welcoming and encouraging environment
Yes, if you are looking for a creative outlet and insight from people on how to create a compelling visual piece. For a class that teaches hard technical skills in drawing, I would look elsewhere.
Yes. Drawing is a great skill and it was the kind of class that you get out what you put in.
yes! really enjoyed the teaching and the course
yes, this is a fun course, you get to draw

Yes, this course is very friendly. Professor Keegan creates a great atmosphere for student discussion and cares a lot about our reactions, thoughts, and concerns. While there isn't much focus on drawing "better," this course encourages you to create things you may not do on your own if you're not an art student (e.g. self-portrait and collage).
Yes! Especially if youre somewhat intimidated by drawing or not majoring in art. Professor Keegan was great at helping students incorporate outside interests into their work.
Absolutely! Matt's a great instructor, and you'll have a chance to make some pieces you're really proud of.

This was a nice, relaxed course where you learn how to draw with different materials. I was not sure how this course would turn out because of the pandemic, but it went much more smoothly than I thought. Professor Keegan is understanding and also gives good, actionable advice when we were working on our projects. If you've never taken an art class before and want to try something new, I would definitely recommend this course.
Absolutely! A great course to take senior year in my opinion, and I nice was to relax and decompress while still feeling like you are being productive, which I love.
Absolutely - this class taught me so much about different forms of media and was such a nice contemplative pause in my day.
I would recommend this course to a student interested in becoming exposed to art. While not structured, it does provide access to something that not many students at Yale touch.
